name: do command
info:
This node creates a command for a device, i.e. the output can go to `core.std_cmds` or `core.fast_cmds` inputs. General purpose, used to send tuyaDEAMON commands. ### Parameters
remote string | @string | NULL
the tuyaDEAMON instance (as in _core.global.remotemap_) or NULL. - Default: NULL => delete 'remote' (i.e. local) - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a string, e.g. `foo` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.instance_name` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@Date.now()` - runtime override: from `msg.command.remote` value
device string | @string | NULL
the device user-name or `ID` or `CID` (as in _core.global.alldevices_). - Default: NULL => delete 'device' - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a string, e.g. `core` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.instance_name` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@Date.now()` - runtime override: from `msg.command.device` value
property string | @string | NULL
the data point ID or user.name (string: "3" or "_version") - Default: NULL => delete 'property' - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a string, e.g. `_DBase` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.instance_name` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@Date.now()` - runtime override: from `msg.command.property` value
valueany | @string | NULL
the new value to send to the device (unencoded). - Default: NULL => delete 'value' - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: boolean | number | string | JSON object, as required by DP definition in `global.alldevices` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.instance_name` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@Date.now()` - runtime override: from `msg.command.value` value
### Input Any, used only to provoke the output, but values like `msg.command.remote` can override the parameters. ### Output A standard tuyaDAEMON msg command. ### Details Standard message structure ```` object { payload :{ remote: , device: , property: , value: }} ```` rules: ```` if remote = NULL (or missed) => local instance. if device = NULL (or missed) and remote valid => GET remote device list elseif property = NULL (or missed) => GET device SCHEMA elseif value = NULL (or missed) => GET property else => SET property ```` ###References For command format, see `std_cmds` and `fast_cmds` nodes in 'CORE' flow.

name: make msg
info: Implements 'NULL' rules, format output.

name: late binding
info:
See [Subflows and configuration: late and runtime parameters binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042)

Modified:
- added evalued binding: @<expression>  => eval(<expression>). e.g. `@Date.now()` 
- runtime override: uses `msg.command.xxx`

name: REFRESH
info:
Use this subflow to drive devices with `REFRESH` capability. It acts like a filter on device msg, intercepts and implements two pseudo-DP to handle the REFRESH: - SET `_refreshCycle` ` off| time [s]` : off/on polling - GET `_refreshCycle` : back last value - SET `_refresh` `dummy` : immdiate REFRESH - GET `_refresh` ignored ### Parameters
deviceId string
The ID of the wired Tuya device (same as in `core.global.alldevices`).
Max_time number
Timeout [s] for `_refreshCycle`, without `stop` message. - Default: `global.MAXREFRESH`, a common value for all devices. If the user like, it can use a different 'global' value for any device. - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a number, e.g. `60` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.MAXREFRESH` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@global.get('MAXREFRESH')*3`
### Inputs All low level messages for a device. ### Outputs 1. To device: all input messages, less `_refresh` and `_refreshCycle`, plus 'REFRESH' messages for the device. 2. To logging: some log messages. ### Details Some devices (e.g. AC power meter) convert and send data (PUSH) at very low frequence, and a GET returns the last PUSHed data. But sometime, e.g. when the UI is open, it is better to uptate the interface at a faster rate (smartLife app uses 5s). If the device implements the REFRESH command, the user can send two pseudoDP: 1. `_refresh`: to convert and GET an immediate value (PUSH). 2. `_refreshCycle`: to start a automatic PUSH cycle, with an user defined rate, until a 'stop' command or until 'Max time' has expired. note: add in alldevices the device.capability 'REFRESH', else ERROR message. ### References For the native documentation see [tuyapi](https://codetheweb.github.io/tuyapi/index.html#tuyadevicerefresh) and [node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device](https://github.com/vinodsr/node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device#input-format)
For device message formats see `low_level_IN` 'core' node

name: REFRESH control
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

- duplicate this node for any new device
- update in code the deviceId
  
see: [Howto: add a new device to tuyaDAEMON](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/Howto:-add-a-new-device-to-tuyaDAEMON)

name: late binding
info:
See [Subflows and configuration: late and runtime parameters binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042)

Modified:
- added evalued binding: @<expression>  => eval(<expression>). e.g. `@Date.now()`

name: dynamic retry
info:
Transform the `status` msg from a _tuya-smart-device_ node into an _event_ message. Implement a dynamic retry policy. ### Parameters
deviceId string
The ID of the wired Tuya device (same as in `core.global.alldevices`).
MinTimeout number | string | @string
Low limit for fast retry [ms]. - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a number | string, e.g. `1000` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.fast-connection` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@1*1000`
MaxTimeout number | string | @string
High limit for slow retry [ms]. - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a number | string, e.g. `60000` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.slow-connection` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@1*60*1000`
### Inputs From _tuya-smart-device_ `client satus` output. ### Outputs 1. **event msg**: a new event message: ```` object { "payload":{ "deviceId": , "data": { "dps":{ "_connected": true|false }}}} ```` It can ben routed to `logging` input node of `core` flow. 2. a **low level SET message**: SET timeout for the device, sent directly to core `low_lev_IN` input node. ```` object { "payload":{ "toDev": idevice, "payload": { "dps": "_findTimeout", "set": }}} ```` ### Details Some devices, usully always ON, requires fast timeout to reconnect soon (see `static retry` subflow), but other devices, sometime OFF, requires a different strategy: `dynamic retry`. This subflow process the `status` output from a tuya-smart-device node. If the connection status changes, it creates an event for standard logging, filtering unecessary messages. Dynamically optimizes the timeout of Tuya device connection attempts (since `smart-tuya-device-node` 4.0.2): - When the device is _connected_, the retry timeout is fast, set to `MinTimeout`. - If the device is _disconnected_, the timeout grows randomly until a `MaxTimeout`. _Example:_ Set in `smart-tuya-device-node`: - `Interval for retry connection` = 1000 (default, 1 sec). - `Connection search interval` = 1000 With the default settings (1s, 60s), the minimum retry interval is approximately _10 seconds_ (affected by many factors). If the device is disconnected, the interval increases in random increments to approximately _sec. 60 in 9/10 minutes_ Use it with Tuya devices often OFF or not in use (e.g. mobile AC plugs). ### References See also `static retry` subflow.
For the native documentation see [node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device](https://github.com/vinodsr/node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device#input-format).
For messages formats see `logging` 'core' node and `low_level_IN` 'core' node.

name: connected message - dynamic
late binding
info:
See [Subflows and configuration: late and runtime parameters binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042)

Modified:
- added evalued binding: @<expression>  => eval(<expression>). e.g. `@Date.now()`

name: do logging
info:
This subflow simulates data received from a _real tuya device_, i.e. it builds an 'event' to be sent to the `core.logging` input. General purpose, used to build events in mirror and fake devices. ### Parameters
remote string | @string | NULL
the tuyaDEAMON instance (as in _core.global.remotemap_) or NULL. - Default: NULL => delete 'remote' (i.e. local) - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a string, e.g. `ANDROID` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.instance_name` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@global.get('instance_name')` - runtime override: from `msg.logging.remote` value
deviceID string | @string
the device user-name or `ID` or `CID` (as in _core.global.alldevices_). - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a string, e.g. `core` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.TUYABRDG` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@"tuya"+"_bridge"` - runtime override: from `msg.logging.deviceID` value
propertyDP string | @string
the data point ID or user.name (string: "3" or "_version") - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a string, e.g. `foo` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.COUNTDP` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@global.get()` - runtime override: from `msg.logging.propertyDP` value
valueany | @string | NULL
the new value from the device. - Default: NULL => "" - uses [late binding](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042) node (extended), and accepts: - early binding: a string, e.g. `foo` - late binding: a string starting with 'global.' | 'flow.' | 'msg.' e.g. `global.instance_name` - evalued value: a string starting with '@', e.g. `@Date.now()` - runtime override: from `msg.logging.value` value
### Input Any, used only to provoke the output, but values like `msg.logging.remote` can override the parameters. ### Output ````` object { "payload": { "remote_from" : , // optional "deviceId": , "data": { "dps": { "" = }}} ````` ### References For event messages format see `logging` INPUT node in 'core' flow.
About mirror devices, see ['Smoke_Detector':-case-study](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/mirror-device-'Smoke_Detector':-case-study)

name: format logging msg
info: implements 'NULL' rules, format output object.

name: static retry
info:
Transform the `status` msg from a _tuya-smart-device_ node into an _event_ message. Required adding a new Tuya device (alternative: `dynamic rety` subflow) ### Parameters
deviceId string
The ID of the wired Tuya device (same as in `core.global.alldevices`).
### Inputs From _tuya-smart-device_ `client satus` output. ### Outputs A new event message: ```` object { "payload":{ "deviceId": , "data": { "dps":{ "_connected": true|false }}}} ```` It can ben routed to _logging_ input node of `core` flow. ### Details Process the `status` output from a tuya-smart-device node. If the connection status changes, it creates an event for standard logging, filtering unecessary messages. Use it with Tuya devices always ON. If the device is disconnected, the reconnect interval, function(findTimeout, retryTimeout), is fixed. It is set in the _tuya-smart-device_ node (default) and modified with the pseudo-dp: - SET `_findTimeout` Integer [ms] - SET `_retryTimeout` Integer [ms] ### References See also `dynamic retry` subflow.
For the event formats see `core.logging` INPUT node.

name: connected message - static
info: Makes  the _event_ message.

label: CORE
info:
The **tuyaDAEMON CORE** handles the LOW LEVEL MQTT communications with devices, offering you a  bidirectional integration with 'real' and 'virtual' Tuya devices.

Version 2.2.0

   see: https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON
   see: https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/tree/main/tuyaDAEMON

### Installation

see [github documentation](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/tree/main/tuyaDAEMON#installation)

### Configuration

Update the node: 'global CORE config': follow the node documentation.
 
 Checklist:
 - in _Global CORE config_ node set the `instance_name`
 - in _Global CORE config_ node update the `remoteMAP` with `instance_name`
 - in _Global CORE config_ node set `alldevice_file_path` to a local value.
 - in all CORE `DB nodes` verify the correct associations with `DB configuration` nodes

Test CORE, then add in sequence (optional):
  - tuyadaemon.core_TRIGGER, configure and test it.
  - tuyadaemon.core_SYSTEM, configure and test it
  - tuyadaemon.core_MQTT, configure and test it

### IMPORTANT: node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device updating.

For better performances with tuyaDAEMON you can replace the standard node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device 4.1.1 with an updated version.
This will produce less 'error messages' and fastest device connections, important factor having many devices.

   - download the file `tuya-smart-device-updated.4.1.1.zip` from https://github.com/vinodsr/node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device/issues/83
   - make a copy of the file "[D:\nodered\flow-1984]\node_modules\node-red-contrib-tuya-smart-device\src\tuya-smart-device.js" as backup.
   - replace "tuya-smart-device.js" with the file in  `tuya-smart-device-updated.4.1.1.zip`
   - done: restart node-red

### Updating devices from a precedent version.

Open tuyaDAEMON new and the old one as well (using a lan or different ports).

In old: select the nodes (device selector, refresh, tuya_smart, retry) and EXPORT to clipboard the 'selected nodes'.

In new: open the 'core' flow and IMPORT from Clipboard (do not replace subflows):
 - Restore connections. 
 - update '*catch device and LAN errors' node
 - Update the global.alldevice from old using 'cut+paste' or the tools: tuyadaemonthings and tuyadamontool.

### Adding new Tuya devices
 see the wiki: https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/Howto:-add-a-new-device-to-tuyaDAEMON
 
### pogrammer's note:
 -  private IN/OUT link nodes for internal flow use: they are all without label and with a special double arrow icon ('fa_expand' icon).
 -  private IN/OUT intra-flows links are without label.
 -  public  IN/OUT link nodes, useful for custom devices or extension flows: they are all labeled and accepted 'msg' formats are in the node documentation.
 

### custom extensions are easy in the areas:
 - new device data encoding/decoding functions, to translate device data into human format. There are now 14 functions, but you can add more for your devices (see '*ENCODE/DECODE user library' node)
 - number and strategy of use of the DBs: the default value is max 2 DBs, and all the event and command logs go into a single DB. Maybe you need to change this (see 'CUSTOMIZE: DBase servers (readme)' node)

name: OUT data process
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

Edit the code to add a new custom decode function.

more: 
1. add the dual custom encode function to the 'format command' node
2. add the dual custom encode function to the 'fastFormat' node
3. add the CODENAME in the `tuyahome.lookupdecode` table.
4. now you can use it in global.alldevices, dp.typefield

name: logging
info:
Main entry point for tuyaDEAMON events/responses.

General format (from tuya-smart-device node, modified):
````
msg.payload:{     
        "remote_from": undefined|remoteName,      // only from remote instance, see global.remotemap
        "deviceId":    gatewayID|deviceid,          // from virtual devices => "deviceId": gatewayId
        "deviceName":  name,                     // from tuya-smart-device node, optional - not used
        "data": {
            "t": Math.floor( Date.now() / 1000 );       // timestamp (sec), from tuya node, optional 
            "cid": deviceid;                                 // only from virtual devices, mandatory
            "dps":{
                [dp]: value                               // encoded, more than one dp in some cases
                ....
            }}}}
````

Fake/custom devices uses a reduced structure:
````
msg.payload:{     
        "remote_from": undefined|SVxx             // only from remote instance, see global.remotemap
        "deviceId":    dev-name|deviceid,        
        "data": {
            "dps":{
                [dp-name|dp]: value                   // one or many dp, native value can be encoded 
                ....
            }}}}
````

CORE processing:
 - fires related 'share' if defined in core.global.alldevices
 - fires actions if user defined in 'mirror' flows.

CORE logging:
 - updates the|many `global.tuyastatus[dev-name][dp-name] = value-decoded`
 - trace on node-red debug.pad
 - send one|many MQTT messages to broker
 - add one|many records to DB
 - send back a HTTP response if started by a REST command.

note
 - if 't' value is missed, it is addeded by CORE.
 - "deviceName" is the tuya-smart-device node name, used only locally in the flow, not used by tuyaDAEMON.

name: format  command
info:
Standard commands process

see 'std_cmds' node.

name: *device selector
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

- For a new device
    - Add one output
    - Add a new rule on 'msg.toDev' property using the deviceID
    - Wire the new output to new 'tuya-smat-device' node.

see: [Howto: add a new device to tuyaDAEMON](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/Howto:-add-a-new-device-to-tuyaDAEMON)

note:
 -  Installing a new devices, use only the 'static retry' node.
 -  When all ok:
     - if the device can be disconnected for longtime (e.g. mobile plugs) better to replace it with 'dinamic retry' node.
     - if  the device can handle the 'REFRESH' command (e.g. AC power meters) you can add the 'REFRESH' node and add `'REFRESH'` to device capabilities in `global.alldevices`.

 - Use in 'device selector', 'REFRESH', 'tuya-smarty-device', 'static/dinamic retry' the SAME `deviceID` as in `global.alldevices`.
 
 - The position 1 is reserved to 'tuya_brige' device.

name: std_cmds
info:
Main entry point for tuyaDEAMON commands:

For a great incapsulation, external application can use only `usr-device-name`, `usr-property-name` and `usr-decoded-data`, as defined by [global.alldevices.](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/tuyaDAEMOM-global.alldevices) 

note: user-namers can change in any moment, so TuyaDAEMON, extensions, fake devices must use the deviceID, dp, and encoded data.

`msg.payload` for **SET** command (to set a device status or to trigger an action, in this case value MUST exist but it is discarted)
````
{  "remote"  : undefined|`SVRxxx`,        //  remote tuyaDEAMON ID, optional: see global.remotemap. 
   "device"  : `dev-usr`|`cid`|`id`,      //  device-name.
   "property": `dp-usr`|`pseudoDP`|`dp`,  //  propery-name 
   "value"   : `any`|`accepted_value` }   //  uncoded value (see alldevice: 'type' and 'typefiel')
````

`msg.payload` for **GET** command (to get a value asking the device or using last from **global.tuyastatus** ):
````
{  "remote"  : undefined|`SVRxxx`,        //  remote tuyaDEAMON ID, optional: see global.remotemap. 
   "device"  : `dev-usr`|`cid`|`id`,      //  device-name.
   "property": `dp-usr`|`pseudoDP`|`dp`}  //  propery-name 
````

`msg.payload` for **GET schema** command (send to device or get value from **global.tuyastatus** ):
````
{  "remote"  : undefined|`SVRxxx`,    //  remote tuyaDEAMON ID, optional: see global.remotemap. 
   "device"  : `dev-usr`|`cid`|`id` } //  device-name.
````

`msg.payload` for **device LIST** from a remote tuyaDAEMON instance:
````
{  "remote"  : `SVRxxx`,              //  remote tuyaDEAMON ID: see global.remotemap. 
````

`msg.payload` for **SET multiple** command (_deprecated because uses dps index and coded data_):
````
{  "remote"  : undefined|`SVRxxx`,       //  remote tuyaDEAMON ID, optional: see global.remotemap. 
   "device"  : `dev-usr`|`cid`|`id`,     //  device-name.
   "property": `MULTIPLE`,               //  pseudoOP
   "value"   : {dp1:val1, dp2:val2...}}  //  coded values 
````


**Commands handling**
Others CORE INPUT nodes: 
   -  'fast_cmds'    (no logTX, std msg), 
   -  'fake_cmds_IN' (no logTX, normalized msg),
   -  'low_level_in' (no logTX, native device msg + pseudoDP), 
   -  'share_in'     (no logTX, share msg).

name: OUT msg process
info:
_tuyaDAEMON process chain for messages coming from all device._

Input: msg from any `smart-tuya-device` node or from 'fake' devices or internally generated.

Ouput: 
  - the global.tuyastatus object is updated.
  - a log of every received data is stored in the 'messages' DB table.
  - info, trace and warning messages are output on the debug pad.
  
The user can control the info and trace messages and select the stored records.

name: *trace: msg OUT from all devices
info:
CUSTOMIZATION

- Enable to see in the debug pad all msg sended from all devices.
- Normal use: disabled

name: low_level_IN

info:
CUSTOMIZATION

- duplicate for any new device alltime connected
- set properties: deviceID.

for more info: see "*device selector" node documentation.

name: Debug pad trace
info:
COSTOMIZATION:

 - Disable unwonted trace nodes.
 
 - Warn/ERROR messages are alway sended.

name: EXPORT alldevices,json
info:
Command to export a file 'alldevices.json'.
note: the output path is defined in 'global CORE config' node.

name: low_level_OUT
info:
Low level output, all messages as sended by devices.

The messages are unprocessed, directly from `tuya-smart-device` node. 

_Used by_:  `tuyaTRIGGERS.'event trigger'` node

_See also_: `'to logging'` input link node for the OUT msg structure.

OUT msg structures:

example: msg (real)
 ````
        {
        _msgid: "12342f3fd.8697fc"
        _event: "node:12343963.a7d846"
        payload: object
           deviceId: "123455aa196ae5975cy6ii"
           deviceName: "*tuya_bridge" 
           data: object
              t: 1609234903  // timestamp, in seconds.
              dps: object
                 102: 1020   // array of dp:value
        }
```` 

example msg: (virtual)
````
        {
        _msgid: "12346a44.e81238"
        payload: object
           deviceId: "123473b1b789b4994cro7p"
           deviceName: "Zigbee Gateway"
           data: object
              cid: "12348d00856a1c15"
              t: 1609235292
              dps: object
                 102: 1020   // array of dp:value
        }             
````

name: tuyaDAEMON CORE 2.2.0
all: filter&update
Info events filter
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

Filter to reduce info messages on Debug pad.

Filtering action is done usually by the 'hide' device/dp property, under user control.
Some cases are done by this code, to force default behavior.

- On installation and test:
  Best don't filter any message.
- On production:
  Better to filter not useful events.

_________________________________
  
In code, filter can be done on: 
       msg.from:            RX info, the deviceId
       msg.to:              TX info, the deviceId
       msg.infodp:          the dpId

name: *DB command filter
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

1) To kill all DB record for a device or dp (better to use the "hide" property in global.alldevices)
2) To route commands in more than one DB
3) To implement new commands to use more than two DB.

note: this NOT requires _system, but it implements some features
    required by _system, processing "_sqlBDxxxx" commands.

- update the code for any change in  _system "_sqlBDxxxx" commands.

name: to system.conn_ev_IN
info:
TRIGGER internal/external.

Fired at any change of devices connection status.
This event is logged and fires an update of AC/LAN/AC properties in _system

limit throughput, but allows smooth operations and less connection problems

note: node not usable for fast rates: internal delay limit about 690/10s

name: *All DB status
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

Add here all DB node used (now 3)

name: DB check
DB_ALARM
info:
TRIGGER for user flows (actually not used by tuyaDAEMON).

Fired at any DN status change.

name: interface
rest_automata
REST HTTP
info:
The **tuyaDAEMOM REST** is implemented using two interfaces, for different pourposes.

1) **/tuyaDEAMON:** this is the production interface, always fast.

2) **/tuyaDEAMONdebug:** this is the development interface, waits the device answer.

see https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/tuyaDAEMON-REST
For examples: see test nodes.

name: Global CORE config

properties.to: {"real":[{"id":"example1234567","name":"tuya_bridge","device":"switch-1CH","power":"UPS","dps":[{"dp":1,"name":"relay","capability":"WW","typefield":"BOOLEANONOFF"},{"dp":7,"name":"trigger (reserved)","capability":"TRG","type":"int","comment_01":"Values: 0..86500 s  (24H max.)"},{"dp":14,"name":"restart status","capability":"WW","type":"string","comment_01":"Values: off|on|memory"},{"dp":15,"name":"light mode","capability":"WW","type":"string","comment_01":"Values: pos|none|relay"},{"dp":16,"name":"backlight","capability":"WW","type":"boolean","comment_01":"Values: true|false "},{"dp":17,"name":"circulate","capability":"WW","typefield":"STRUCTREPEAT"},{"dp":18,"name":"random","capability":"WW","typefield":"STRUCTRAND"},{"dp":19,"name":"inching","capability":"WW","typefield":"STRUCTINCH"},{"dp":"_tstPing"},{"dp":"_testPing24H","comment":"NO code implementation, only 'share'","capability":"SKIP","share":[{"test":["msg.info.value.count > 0"],"action":[{"device":"tuya_bridge","property":"_tstPing","value":true},{"device":"_system","property":"_timerON","value":"@ _xy = {timeout:600000, id:'_testPing24H', alarmPayload:{device:'tuya_bridge', property:'_testPing24H',value: {count:(msg.info.value.count -1)}}}; _xy "}]}]}]}],"virtual":[],"fake":[{"id":"_core","name":"core","device":"_core","power":"AC","capability":["SET","GET","SCHEMA"],"dps":[{"dp":"_DBase","capability":"RO"},{"dp":"_heartbeat","capability":"RO","typefield":"TSTAMP2TIME"},{"dp":"_info","name":"version"}]},{"id":"_system","name":"HAL@home","device":"_system","capability":["SET","GET","SCHEMA"],"dps":[{"dp":"_doSCHEMA","type":"string"},{"dp":"_doUPDATE"},{"dp":"_ACpower","capability":"RO","type":"boolean"},{"dp":"_ACunconnected","capability":"RO"},{"dp":"_beep","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_benchmark"},{"dp":"_benchmark_end","capability":"TRG","hide":"K"},{"dp":"_benchmark_step","capability":"TRG","hide":"K"},{"dp":"_doBenchmark"},{"dp":"_doTrigger","capability":"WO","type":"int"},{"dp":"_LANnet","capability":"RO","type":"boolean"},{"dp":"_laststart","capability":"RO","type":"string"},{"dp":"_name","capability":"RO","type":"string"},{"dp":"_play","capability":"WO","type":"see note"},{"dp":"_proxy","capability":"RW"},{"dp":"_exec","type":"string"},{"dp":"_sqlDBlocal","type":"string"},{"dp":"_sqlDBremote","type":"string"},{"dp":"_timerList","capability":"RO"},{"dp":"_timerOFF","type":"string"},{"dp":"_timerON"},{"dp":"_toDebug","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_toFastIN","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_toLogging","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_toLowIN","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_toShare","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_toStdCmd","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_toWarn","capability":"WO","type":"string"},{"dp":"_tuyastatus","capability":"WO"},{"dp":"_WiFinet","capability":"RO"},{"dp":"_WiFiunconnected","capability":"RO"},{"dp":"_beep_loop","comment":"NO code implementation, omly 'share'","capability":"SKIP","share":[{"test":["msg.info.value.count > 0"],"action":[{"device":"_system","property":"_beep","value":1},{"device":"_system","property":"_timerON","value":"@ _xy = {timeout:msg.info.value.timeout, alarmPayload:{device:'_system', property:'_beep_loop',value: {count:(msg.info.value.count -1), timeout: msg.info.value.timeout}}}; _xy "}]},{"test":["msg.info.value.count == 0"],"action":[{"device":"_system","property":"_toLogging","value":{"deviceId":"_system","data":{"dps":{"_beep_loop":"done"}}}}]}]},{"dp":"_beep_loop2","comment":"alternative implementation","capability":"SKIP","share":[{"test":["msg.info.value.count > 0"],"action":[{"device":"_system","property":"_beep","value":1},{"device":"_system","property":"_timerON","value":{"timeout":"@msg.info.value.timeout","alarmPayload":{"device":"_system","property":"_beep_loop2","value":{"count":"@msg.info.value.count -1","timeout":"@msg.info.value.timeout"}}}}]}]},{"dp":"_zeroLog","share":[{"action":[{"device":"_system","property":"_benchmark_step","value":"any"}]}]},{"dp":"_zeroTask","hide":"K","share":[{"action":[{"device":"_system","property":"_benchmark_step","value":"any"}]}]}]}]}

info:
## CORE Configuration

_global.alldevices_
    To add a _new device_, or for fine tune an existing one, or to add `share` actions.
    Same in all instances.
      - see: https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/tuyaDAEMOM-global.alldevices
      - see also: https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/tuyaDAEMON-toolkit

_global.remotemap_
    Mandatory for every tuyaDAEMON instance.
    Two URLs for every instance in LAN.
    Same in all instances.
     - see: https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/ver.-2.0--milestones#net-extensions

_global.instance_name_
    The name of this instance.
    note: used also in remotemap.

_flow.alldevice_file_path_
    The dir to save a copy of alldevices (node 'EXPORT alldevices')
    note:
    - See also the tuyadaemontoolkit and tuyadaemonthings applications, for the management of alldevices.
    - If 'tuyadaemontoolkit' is installed, use:
        ...tuyadeamontoolkit\devicedata
        
### DataBase SETUP
  _This implementeation can use 0, 1, or 2 Dbases_ :
   CORE uses only the DB tuyathome.messages table to store log messages (see 'BD command filter' node )
   
  The two databases are called: 'DBlocal' and 'DBremote'.
     - setup 'MySQL configuration' nodes for the DBlocal and/or DBremote.
     - on DBlocal (but can be really a remote DB, changing the configuration)  CORE can store the log of all commands ('TX') and events ('RX') processed.
     - the BDremote is used only to send user sql ( property  _systen._sqlDBremote).
     - disable DBlocal/DBremote nodes if not used (default).
      
  notes
   - The user can fine tuning the log to only interesting data, on device/property basis, in the global.alldevices structure [see the wiki](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/tuyaDAEMOM-global.alldevices#output-control).
   - With 'system' the user can send custom SQL commands to both DBs: see SYSTEM test nodes for some examples..

  Extensions
   - If you must use more than two DBs, it is easy to duplicate the nodes structure, for details see 'CUSTOMIZE: DBase servers (readme)' node documentation.
   - An WAMP/LAMP server is used by default, but you can easily change the flow to use different DBs if you wish.

### new DEVICES SETUP: 
    click the comment node 'CUSTOMIZE LOW_LEVEL (real) tuya devices' for info.
    
  note
    - To add new encode/decade functions to handle new formats of device data,  see the node: '*ENCODE/DECODE user library'.
        
        
 note: the tuyaDAEMON three step startup process:

  ------------ On Start:
  - All 'Global MODULE config' nodes updates global/flow values
  - 'On Start' in all flow/nodes: can do init tasks, and set
       global/flow/context values, bur CAN NOT use global/flow values
    (note: the esecution order is undefined)
 
  ------------ CORE setup (first)
    note: after All 'On Start':
  - set libraries and objects in context.global
  - run also 'core flow setup' (can use context.global)

  ----------- all other MODULES setup (delayed)
  - run all 'module flow setup' (can use context.global)
  - ERROR msg if CORE setup not finish (fine tune the 'start delay')
    (note: the esecution order is undefined)

CUSTOMIZATION

  - duplicate for any new device
  - set proprties: deviceId (or IP), key, retry timeout (1000 ms), find timeout (5000 ms).

CUSTOMIZATION

  - duplicate for any new device
  - set proprties: deviceId (or IP), key, retry timeout (1000 ms), find timeout (5000 ms).

Edit for DB url and credentials. 
Disable/delete if not used.

name: share actions
FastFormat
info:
Fast command process
  see 'fast_cmds' node

name: fast_cmds
info:
Fast INPUT (internal use)

Differences from standard INPUT commands:
 
1.  No command echo on debug pad, no log on DB (like hide="CT")

2.  No test of the device capabilities in `alldevices`: all commands are processed. i.e. _use `fast_cmds` with care, only with tested commands._
3.  Only the following capabilities of a DP, defined in `alldevices`, are processed:
 - "SKIP" : the command is not sent to device.
 - "WW" or "GW" : any GET is replaced by SET(null).
 
4.  _We can set `device.capabilities='NONE'` to block all commands from user, but still executing commands from 'fast_cmds'._
 
4.  _We can set `dp.capability='TRG'` to block all commands from user, but still executing commands from 'fast_cmds'._
 
5.  Internal use: share, custom devices, extensions.

6.  For tuyaDEAMON user commands see 'std_cmds' node.

- Normal use: disabled

see: https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/Howto:-add-a-new-device-to-tuyaDAEMON

for more info: see "*device selector" node documentation.

name: share IN
info:
## ENTRY point to execute a 'share'

Usually 'share' are defined in global.alldevices, so an Event can trigger one of more Commands.

But a 'share' can live also alone, and the user as an alternative way to fire commands in tuyaDEAMON, sending here a 'share', or using the SYSTEM property 'doSHARE'.

share object Format:
     "info": {                     // auto from trigger event or user (optional)
                  ""             // used as 'IN parameters' into the expressions
             }
     "share": [{
        "test": [                                      // optional: default true
           `condition-string-1`        // eval(condition-string-1) => true|false          
            ... more test strings (AND) ... ],
        "action": [{                                  // standard command fields
            "remote"  : "NAMEXX",                                    // optional
            "device"  : @expession | string | null | undefined,
            "property": @expession | string | null | undefined,    
            "value"   : @expession | string | object | null | undefined
             } ... more actions (sequence)...]
         } ... more {(test[],) action[]} (selection) ...
      ]

Special rules of evaluation for action.device (and property, value) to build the actual cammand:

    share.action.device = @expession       => command.payload.device = eval(expession)
    share.action.device = string (object)  => command.payload.device = string (object)
    share.action.device = null             => command.payload.device = undefined
    share.action.device = undefined|missed => command.payload.device = info.device || undefined.
    
see [alldevices](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/tuyaDAEMOM-global.alldevices#share-actions)

examples: see in global.alldevices the implementation of this properties, all uses 'share':
      - system._beep_loop  
      - system.doBenchmark
      - tuya_bridge._tstPing24H.

name: CUSTOMIZE (real) tuya devices (readme)
info:
Add here the 'real tuya-devices' i.e. the devices handled by smart-tuya-device node, or equivalent implementations. For more detail, see 'core.devices selector' node informations.

For the the 'virtual tuya-devices' i.e. the devices handled by a gateway, add in this flow only the gateway.

For the 'mirror devices' you MUST add the core_trigger flow.

See in the wiki [how to add a new device](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/Howto:-add-a-new-device-to-tuyaDAEMON)

name: pseudo DPs
fake_cmds_IN
info:
INPUT for direct commands to _local fake devices_.

Command format for all local 'fake' and custom devices:
   the Message is in rich `normalizated` format to speedup next elaborations:

used to update `global.tuyastatus` (are standard items but redefined)
-   `msg.payload.device   = usr-dev-name|msg.to`
-   `msg.payload.property = undef|usr-dp-name|msg.infodp`
-   `msg.payload.value    = undef|any`  

used as keys:
-   `msg.to     = cid|deviceId`       (mandatory)
-   `msg.infodp = dp|pseudoDP`        (mandatory)
-   `msg.hide   = ""|"KCERT"`         (visibility, since 2.2.0)

rules:
- Only for local devices, not handled by the 'tuya-smart-device' nodes.
- pseudoDPs are defined in `global.alldevices.__pseuododp` array.
     [see wiki](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/ver.-2.0--milestones#pseudodp)
- The device|dp `capabilities` are not checked in global.alldevices.
- The device _connection status is not checked.
- SCHEMA: `infodp` = 'schema', `property`= undefined, `value`= undefined
- GET: `value` = undefined
- SET: `value` = defined, any value, also object.

unused in _fake devices_:
-  `msg.toDev  = gatewayId|deviceId` (real devices selector)
-  MULTIPLE: `infodp` = 'multiple', `property` = 'multiple', `value` = coded, sent 'as is' to device.

name: sql_BD
info:
##  Entry point for DB (sql)

Format for tuyaDAEMON DB Logging purpose (routed to DBlocal, no log):

       {
        to|from: `deviceId`|`cid`,  // mandatory
        infodp:  `property`,
        hide: "",
        topic:   "INSERT ..."     // sql
       }
   
Format to execute user sql (routed to DBlocal, DBremote..., with log)

       {
        to:     "_dBase",     
        infodp: "_sqlDBlocal"|"_sqlDBremote"|...,     // default two dp.
        hide: "",
        topic:  `sql-string`
       } 

For more than 2 DB: see
Update the `*DB mux-filter` node.

name: *dynamic retry
info:
Use 'dynamic retry' in place of 'static retry' if the device is often disconneted (power strip, power plug, light bulbs etc.)


for more info: see "*device selector" node documentation.

Some devices acceps as polling the command `REFRESH`.

Example: power meter.

This filter subflow handles the device polling strategy, intercepting and implementing 2 pseudoDP: `_refresh` and `_refreshCycle`.

CUSTOMIZATION

- Enable to see in the debug pad all msg sended to fake devices.
- Normal use: disabled

CUSTOMIZATION

  - duplicate for any new device
  - set proprties: deviceId (or IP), key, retry timeout (1000 ms), find timeout (5000 ms).

me devices acceps as polling the command REFRES.

Example: power meter.

This subflow handle the device polling strategy, implementing 2 pseudoDP: _refresh and refreshCycle.

Use 'dynamic retry' in place of 'static retry' if the device is often disconneted (power strip, power plug, light bulbs etc.)


for more info: see "*device selector" node documentation.

name: notification
Info commands filter
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

Filter to reduce info messages on Debug pad.

Filtering action is done usually by the 'hide' device/dp property, under user control.
Some cases are done by this code, to force default behavior.

- On installation and test:
  Best don't filter any message.
- On production:
  Better to filter not useful events.

_________________________________
  
In code, filter can be done on: 
       msg.from:            RX info, the deviceId
       msg.to:              TX info, the deviceId
       msg.infodp:          the dpId

name: events info
info: Internal use, to send via new protocols (actually used by MQTT).

name: commands info
info: internal use, to send via new protocols (actually not used)

name: CUSTOMIZE: DBase servers (readme)
info:
_This implementeation can use 0, 1, or 2 Dbases_ :
  
  The two databases are called: 'DBlocal' and 'DBremote'.
     - on DBlocal (but it can be really a remote DB, changing the configuration)  CORE stores the log of all commands ('TX') and events ('RX') processed.
     - CORE uses only the 'tuyathome.messages' DB table to store log messages (see core.'BD command filter' node)
     - With 'system' the user can send custom SQL commands to both DBs ([see wiki](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/custom-device-_system#db-functions), using two ad hoc properties: '_sqlDBlocal' and 'sqlDBremote'.
     - disable DBlocal/DBremote nodes if not used (default).
     - setup 'MySQL configuration' nodes for the DBlocal and/or DBremote.


   **Extensions**
   Maybe you like to do something like this:
      - to store only some devices/properties in an open 'wehater' DB,
      - to store other devices/properties in a 'security' DB installed in a protected server running 24/7
      - and the others in the 'debug' DB on the development PC.
   
   You can: if you need to use more than two DBs with the same tuyaDAEMON instance, it is easy to duplicate the  DBremote node structure and configuration as required.
   
   1. In 'CORE' flow you must do:
        - Add the required nodes.
        - edit 'DB command filter' node adding more outputs 
        - edit 'DB log event filter' to routing messages.
        - edit 'All DB status' node to check the new DB nodes
        
   2. In 'SYSTEM' flow you must add new commands (new DPs: e.g. 'sqlDBweater') to send SQLs to new DBs. You must modify:
        -  '_system custom selector (3)'  node to implement SET and GET.

   3. finally update
        -  global.alldevices.fake._system (add to _system the new commands (DPs))
   
  An WAMP/LAMP server is used by default, but you can easily change the flow to use different DBs if you wish.

name: *DB events filter
info:
CUSTOMIZATION:

Filter to reduce info record on Databases.

Filtering action is done usually by the 'hide' device/dp property, under user control.
Some cases are done by this code, to force default behavior.

- On installation and test:
  Best don't filter any message.
- On production:
  Better to filter not useful events.

_________________________________

Routing action to direct some records to special DBs.

_________________________________
  
In code, selection can be done on: 
       msg.from:            RX info, the deviceId
       msg.to:              TX info, the deviceId
       msg.infodp:          the dpId          
_________________________________

name: CORE startup process (readme)
info:
Message from CORE (alone) on startup (only if DB nodes are enabled):

    ["RX: 'HAL@home'/'_DBase' ",true]  

or, in case of DB problems (check configuration nodes):  

    msg : error
    "Error: connect ECONNREFUSED 192.168.1.19:3306" (can change)

    ["RX: 'HAL@home'/'_DBase' ", false ] 

Tipical startup sequence (core+system+trigger+MQTT) after a 'Restart Flows':

           [ "RX: core/_DBase", true ]                       // DB very fast

           [ "RX: tuya_bridge/_connected", false ]           // initial value
           [ "RX: HAL@home/_WiFinet", false ]
           [ "RX: HAL@home/_WiFiunconnected", array[1] ]

           [ "RX: tuya_bridge/_connected", true ]            // successful attempt 
           [ "RX: HAL@home/_LANnet", true ]
           [ "RX: HAL@home/_WiFinet", true ]
           [ "RX: HAL@home/_WiFiunconnected", array[0] ]

           [ "RX: core/_heartbeat", "16:46:44" ]             // 5s from start
                                                             // then every 30s
           
           ["RX: HAL@home/_laststart","2022-04-08 16:46:49"] // 10 s from start


**heartbeat**

    ["DEVPC: RX: 'core'/'heartbeat' ","20:57:56"]
    
This is a PUSH event from core, default is every 30s after 5s.

 note:  You can:
 - change the period (editing the 'heartbeat' input node) 
 - control the logging rules ('hide' in global.alldevices, default: "R" = do not store in DBase) 
 - eliminate it (disabling the node).
  
  
**version**
  See the test node "GET version" readme.

name: heartbeat
info:
heartbeat event creation.

PUSH event usend in tests, as watchog, etc.

The payload is from "core.heartbeat" node, fired every 5s (default, defined in the 'heartbeat' node).

To reduce the heartbeat visibility update the 'hide' in 'global.alldevices.fake.core.dps._heartbeat' (general rule): 

  - Set 'hide' to "" | "K" | "E" | "R" to log: all | nothing | only DB | only debugpad + MQTT (it is an event, so do not use "C" and "T").

name: SET info
info:
Test the SET '_info' property of core, using the msg:

         payload: {
            device: "_core",
            property: "_info",
            value: "any"
            }

- Returns the list of modules in use and the list of actually connected devices, gouped as real, virtual and fake devices.

IN _global.alldevices_ the default definition is:

                {
                    "dp": "_info",
                    "name": "version",
                    "capability": "RW"
                }

note: this SET acts as a trigger ( 'value' is requited, but not used) and the result is an updated data structure.
---------------------------------------
Expected result

    TX: GET fake core/version
    
then: 

    ["RX: core/version object] 
  
Openninig the answer object we get (configuration dependent):

 - minimal (only core)
````
    array[2]
      0: "RX: core/version "
      1: object
                      // here list of 'connected' devices
         devices: object
           real: array[0]
           virtual: array[0]
           fake: array[1]
              0: "core"
                      // here list of 'enabled' flows
         core: "2.2.0"
````
- rich (core+trigger+mqtt+system):
````
    array[2]
      0: "RX: core/version "
      1: object
         devices: object
           real: array[1]
             0: "tuya_bridge"
          virtual: array[0]
          fake: array[2]
             0: "core"
             1: "HAL@home"
      core_system: "2.2.0"
      core_trigger: "2.2.0"
      core_mqtt: "2.2.0"
      core: "2.2.0"
````  

_General rule: if you set a user friendly 'name' for a device and/or a property (in core.global.alldevices) all output messages and the global.tuyastatus will use this name (e.g. version vs. _info)._

- _In the input messages you can use both, the name or the ID:_
````
    payload.property = "version"
or    
    payload.property = "_info"      

````
 - Never change strings starting with '_': they are  code defined IDs and cannot be changed.

To have a more rich test experince, this subflow implementation follows the rules:

1) if you set as value any string that starts with:
    -  global.
    -  flow.
    -  msg.

the value is keep from the object you entered.
[See](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/subflows-and-configuration-late-and-runtime-parameters-binding/60042)

example:

   `global.tuyastatus.core._heartbeat` 

instances the parameter to last heartbeat time like `"19:06:44"`


2) The special value `"NULL"` deletes the propery.

Exanple:

   `remote = SOME`
   
output msg:  
````
   msg.payload: {
              "remote_from" : "SOME",   
              "deviceId" : <deviceID>
              ..... more
````   
but:
   `remote = NULL`
   
output msg:  
````
   msg.payload: {
               "deviceId" : <deviceID>
              ..... more
````

name: TESTING CORE Command process (readme)
info:
Testig command (standard/fast) core function.

This examples build a cammand message.

**tuyaDAEMON commands**
````
        "payload": {
              "remote"  : undefined | <remote>,      
              "device"  : undefined | <usr-devname>|<deviceID>
              "property": undefined | <usr-propname>|<propertyDP>
              "value"   : undefined | <as-required (decoded)>
        }}}}

rules:
if remote =    undefined => local instance (remote requires SYSTEM module)
if device =    undefined (remote MUST exist) => get the list of remote devices 
                 else it MUST exist in global.alldevices else ERROR
if property =  undefined  (device MUST exist) => SCHEMA (test: allowed by device?)
                 else (device MUST exist and) it MUST exist in global.alldevices else ERROR
if value =     undefined  (property MUST exist)  =>   GET (test: allowed by dp?)
                 else  (property MUST exist ) =>   SET (test: allowed by dp?) and type checked against global.alldevices or by an optional encode function: else ERROR
````

Differences  `fast_cmds` vs. `std_cmds`:
- fast_cmds: device capabilities are not checked.
- fast_cmds: only "SKIP", "WW", "GW" DP capabilities (in global.alldevices) are tested to process commands.
- fast_cmds: no command log (as hide="CT")


**case ok:**
 - remote:  NULL (to use this test: chhose NULL = undefined / delete)
 - deviceID: e.g. core
 - propertyPD: must exist in global.alldevices | NULL (SCHEMA)
         e.g. NULL |  _info
 - value: NULL (GET) | as required by propertyPD (SET)

Expected result (local.code._info GET) like:
     
      TX: GET fake core/version                         // not in case of 'fast_cmds'

then:     
 
      ["RX: core/version","none"]    // after startup, before any core._info.SET(any)

or:      
      ["RX: core/version", object]                     // after a core._info.SET(any)


**Error messages:**
 bad remote (both Std/Fast):
      ASSERT fail: 'remote' requires the '_system' module installed.       

 bad deviceID (both Std/Fast):
      ERROR [normalize]: not found the device 'fake' in global.alldevices.

 bad propertyDP (both Std/Fast):
 
      WARNING [normalize]: In alldevices missed the 'core':dps[fake] definition."     
 
    then (Std Cmds):
      ERROR: The _core device does not implement the 'fake' property
 
  or (Fast Cmds): 
      TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'capability')

xamples

1. GET core.version local:

> remote:   NULL
> device:   core
> property: version
> value:    NULL

Expected result (configuration dependent)

     ["RX: 'core/version' object] 

2. GET locale device list

 > remote:   global.instance_name   
 > device:   NULL
 > property: NULL
 > value:    NULL

Expected result (requires system, configuration dependent)

      [ "DEVPC: RX: HAL@home/list", array[3] ]
          (DEVPC = actual local instance name)

expanded:

    array[2]
        0: "DEVPC: RX: HAL@home/list"
        1: array[3]
            0: "HAL@home"
            1: "core"
            2: "tuya_bridge"

name: core internal  structures init- do not change
info:
## internal CORE Configuration
do not change.

 _global.json_library_
    Jscript code: do not modify.
    Same in all instances.
    Since 2.2.0
    
 _tuyastatus_        
    The empy object '{}' forces the cleanup of tuyastatus at startup: do not modify.
    Same in all instances.

 _modules_	
    The empy object '{}' forces the cleanup of modules
    at startup: do not modify.
    Same in all instances.

name: save
core properties
initialize:
// for _heartbeat,  inizialize local with a valid timestamp
flow.set("lastts", Date.now());
info:
Catch 'core' SET / GET commands and implements it.
The others messages goes to output.

Genaral rules about device implementation

> 1) SET changes a value (or Data Point).
>     Returns this value (or the value actually set, if different: e.g. rounded)
>     or
>     SET is used as a trigger to activate some internal device operations.
>     The value (which MUST exist because it is a SET) can be discarded ('any').
>     SET returns the result value.
>   
>   2) GET returns the actual value, also from tuyastatus for simplicity.
>      Repeatable, without side effects.
>
>   3) SCHEMA, if implemented, MUST return the actual value for all GETtables DP of the device.
>      The data can be an array of {dp: value} in a single message (tuyaDEAMON records this as separate msg) or the device can return a message for each DP.
 >   
>    4) REFRESH, if implemented, MUST produce the (eventual) update of some internal Data Points and return only the modified DPs.

name: fake_cmds
info:
OUTPUT for commands to fake devices, unprocessed by tuyaDAEMON CORE.

Flows implementing "fake" devices receive their inputs from this node.

Same message format as'fake_cmds_IN' INPUT (see).

name: GET _DBase
info:
Test a GET _DBase property of core.
  
      payload: {
           device: "_core",
           property: "_DBase"
           }   
         
- Returns the last '_DBase' status

IN global.alldevices the default definition is:

               {
                  dp: "_DBase"
                  capability: "RO"   
                  type: "boolean"
               },
               
This property 'PUSH's any variation. The user can only GET 
last PUSHed value (in globel.alldevices capability: "RO", i.e. 'read only')
----------------------
Expected result

    TX: GET fake core/_DBase
    
then: 

    ["RX: core/_DBase none]    // all DB disabled
    ["RX: core/_DBase false]   // error in one (or more) DB
    ["RX: core/_DBase true]    // all DBs connected.

name: GET version
info:
Test the GET '_info' property of core, using the msg:

         payload: {
            device: "_core",
            property: "version",
            }

 Returns last list of modules and devices in use or 'none'
----------------------
Expected result

     TX: GET fake core/version
    
then: 

Before you use an _info(SET) command you get 'none'.

     ["RX: core/version","none"]

After any _info(SET) command you get the last data
i.e. same response as last SET (see 'SET info' node).

name: GET _heartbeat
info:
Test a GET _heartbeat property of core.
  
      payload: {
           device: "_core",
           property: "_heartbeat"
           }   
         
- Returns the last '_heartbeat' time.

IN global.alldevices the default definition is:

               {
                    "dp": "_heartbeat",
                    "hide": "R",
                    "capability": "RO",
                    "typefield": "TSTAMP2TIME"
                }
               
This property 'PUSH's at regular frequence (see 'heartbeat' node). The used can only GET last PUSHed value (in global.alldevices capability: "RO", i.e. 'read only') .

note:
 - "typefield": "TSTAMP2TIME" defines the decoding data function.
 - "hide": "R" to not save in DB _heartbeat records.
 
----------------------
Expected result

     "TX: GET fake core/_heartbeat"
then
     [ "RX: core/_heartbeat", "09:27:31" ]

name: core flow startup
info:
## Programme's note on startup.

The flows STARTUP is a three step pocess:

1. The 'On Start' execution
   - `node-red` grants that all 'on-start' code is executed before the flow start.
   - None is defined about the order of execution for 'On Start' code in different nodes.
   - So any flow 'On Start' (on  "xxxx flow startup" node) can contain standalone global/flow initializations, but not requiring 'global' and 'global.objects'.
2. The global.objects construction is done asap by CORE flow ('*ENCODE/DECODE user library' and 'Global Objects constructor' nodes)
   - After that the CORE executes the "core flow startup" (using also global.objects).
   - At end CORE set the global flag "coresetup" to `true`.
3. Finally, all other flow, after the test of "coresetup", can do the required
jobs in "xxxx flow startup" nodes.

note:
If the "coresetup" test fails, you get the message "STARTUP ERROR: adjust this startup delay."
In this case fine tune the start delay of  "xxxx flow startup" nodes (function of host performances)
Example: core = 0.1 (minimal); other modules: on WIN11 = 0.4, on ANDROID = 1

name: GET core SCHEMA
info:
Test a GET SCHEMAt property of core.
````  
      payload: {
           device: "_core",
           }   
````         
- Equivalent to
````
    for any 'core' GETtable property:
       do GET property
````
----------------------

Expected result

    TX: GET SCHEMA: fake core
    
    
then: 

    ["RX: core/_DBase",true]
    ["RX: core/_heartbeat","09:10:49"]
    ["RX: core/version","none"]           // can be different after a SET(_info)
little delay to allow startup run.

name: REST:     http://localhost:1984/tuyaDAEMON?device=core&property=_info&value=ok

Use this URL in a browser. You must update server and port.

Espected response:

 {"device":"core","property":"version","remote_from":"DEVPC","status":"sent"} (JSON)
 
 note: it is a SET, always the immediate REST response is 'sent'.
 You can later use a GET to get the values.

{"device":"core","property":"_DBase","remote_from":"DEVPC","value":true} (JSON)

name: REST:     http://localhost:1984/tuyaDAEMON?device=core
Same tests using REST (readme)
info:
All tuyaDEAMON commads and events can be handled via http REST

REST URL (update the host:port to select tuyaDEAMON instance):
````    
  http://<localhost:1984>/tuyaDAEMON[?device=<device>[&property=<property>[&value=<JSON value>]]]
````

note:
1. REST commands are handled only on local instance. 'remote' not implemented.
2. Special REST case, only   `http://<localhost:1984>/tuyaDAEMON` 

  Response, JSON device list (from global.tuyastatus keys):
````
                 {
                 "remote_from":"DEVPC",
                 "list":[
                     "core"
                     ]
                 }
````
3. else as standard tuyaDEAMON SCHEMA, GET, SET commands.

Examples tested using 'chrome' as browser.

name: TESTING CORE SHARE commands (readme)
info:
Testig SHARE command (share IN) core function.


This example build an user 'share' message.

**tuyaDEAMON user share**
    
```
     "info": {                     
                  ""        // any, used as 'IN parameters' into the expressions
             }
     "share": [{
        "test": [                                      // optional: default true
           `condition-string-1`        // eval(condition-string-1) => true|false          
            ... more test strings (AND) ... ],
        "action": [{                                  // standard command fields
            "remote"  : "NAMEXX",                                    // optional
            "device"  : @expession | string | null | undefined,
            "property": @expession | string | null | undefined,    
            "value"   : @expession | boolean | int | string | object | null | undefined
             } ... more actions (sequence)...]
         } ... more {(test[],) action[]} (selection) ...
      ]
    
```
Special rules of evaluation for action.device (and property, value) to build the actual cammand:
    
```
    share.action.device = @expession       => command.payload.device = eval(expession)
    share.action.device = string (object)  => command.payload.device = share.action.device
    share.action.device = null             => command.payload.device = undefined
    share.action.device = undefined|missed => command.payload.device = info.device || undefined.
````
[see](https://github.com/msillano/tuyaDAEMON/wiki/tuyaDAEMOM-global.alldevices#share-actions)

name: user share
info:
Sample 'share'

Using a 'share' to build a conditional command.

rule: 

     if (actual-time > info.start (e.g. "11:00:00")) do:
            GET   core._info()
     else do:
            GET   core._DBase()

note: this implementation requires _heartbeat running:

     "test": ["tuyastatus.core._heartbeat > msg.info.start"],


To use a test unrelated to _heartbeat, replace with:

     "test": ["var xnow = new Date();
               (xnow.toLocaleTimeString() > msg.info.start)"],

name: *ENCODE/DECODE user library
info:
CUSTOMIZATION
A new device data format requires two functions: `decode` (to GET data FROM device) and `encode` (to SET user data TO device):

- Edit this node code to add a new custom decode/encode function
- Use same name for both functions (e.g. CODENAME).

then: 
- add the new CODENAME in `tuyahome.lookupdecode` DB table (if you use tuyadaemontoolkit)
- now you can use CODENAME in global.alldevices, in the 'dp.typefield'

name: *pass-all
info:
Thi node do nothing.

It is possible to repalace it wit a

name: Global Objects constructor
TESTING CORE Logging process (readme)
info:
Testig event core function.

This example allow the user to build any event message.

**tuyaDAEMON events** (basic, see `core.logging` node)
````
msg.payload:{     
        "remote_from": undefined|rem-name                  // only if from remote
        "deviceId": deviceID|dev-name       
        "data": {
            "dps":{
                [dp|dp-name]: value                        // encoded if required
                ....                                           // one or more DPs
            }}}}

rules:
remote_from =  undefined => local instance (remote requires SYSTEM module)  
                  else (test: in `global.remotemap`?) 'rem-name' else 'UNKNOWN'.
deviceId  :  MUST exist in `global.alldevices` else ERROR
dp|dp-name  :  MUST exist in `global.alldevices` else WARNING
value     :  if `DP.typefield` exists the value is checked by the decode() function, else any.
````

**case ok:**
 - remote:  NULL (in node `do logging` process: NULL => undefined) or rem-name (from `global.remotemap`)
 - deviceID:    e.g. 'core' or '_core'.
 - propertyPD:  e.g.   `_DBase`, `_heartbeat`...
 - value: Examples
       ` _DBase`: "type": "boolean". Accepted: any.
        `_heartbeat`: "typefield": "TSTAMP2TIME". Accepted timestamp, i.e. any number > 0 (see core.*ENCODE/DECODE user library node).
------------------

Expected result (local.code._heartbeat("123456789")) :
 
      [ "RX: core/_heartbeat", "11:17:36" ]    

Expected result (ANDROID.code._DBase("maybe")) :
    
      ["ANDROID: RX: core/_DBase","maybe"]
 
 
**Error messages:**

 bad remote:

      ASSERT fail: 'remote' requires the '_system' module installed.   
  or:      
      ["UNKNOWN: RX: core/_heartbeat","11:17:36"]

 bad deviceID:
 
      "ERROR [OUT data]: ADD to alldevices the real/fake deviceId: corex (undefined)"
      
 bad propertyDP:
 
      ["WARNING [OUT data]: In alldevices missed the 'core':dps[fake] definition."]

    then (the unknown DPs are always processed to capture rare events from devices):

      ["ANDROID: RX: core/fake","maybe"]
 
 bad value (variable: from decode() function):
    
     ["ANDROID: RX: core/_heartbeat", "Invalid Date"]

xamples

1. GET core.version local:

> remote:   NULL
> device:   core
> property: version
> value:    NULL

Expected result (configuration dependent)

    TX: GET fake 'core'/'version'
    
then: 

    ["RX: 'core/version' object] 

2. GET locale device list

 > remote:   global.instance_name
 > device:   NULL
 > property: NULL
 > value:    NULL

Expected result (requires system, configuration dependent)

      DEVPC: TX: GET device LIST
       (DEVPC = actual local instance name)
      
      [ "TX: SET fake HAL@home/_proxy", object ]
then:

      [ "DEVPC: RX: HAL@home/list", array[3] ]

expanded:

    array[2]
        0: "DEVPC: RX: HAL@home/list"
        1: array[3]
            0: "HAL@home"
            1: "core"
            2: "tuya_bridge"
